titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Thomas S. Mount correspondence 1973.251
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

did.abstract: Correspondence addressed to Thomas S. Mount in Brooklyn and Stony Brook, N.Y. during the period 1871 to 1890. Letters are mostly from publishers of various Long Island newspapers, including the Long Island Reporter, the Long Islander, the Port Jefferson Times and Leader, the Sag Harbor Express, and the South Side Signal, regarding business and financial matters and the publication of advertisements and articles submitted by Mount. Various receipts reflecting Mount's dealings with the newspapers are also included.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Correspondence addressed to Thomas S. Mount in Brooklyn and Stony Brook, N.Y. during the period 1871 to 1890. Letters are mostly from publishers of various Long Island newspapers, including the Long Island Reporter, the Long Islander, the Port Jefferson Times and Leader, the Sag Harbor Express, and the South Side Signal, regarding business and financial matters and the publication of advertisements and articles submitted by Mount. Various receipts reflecting Mount's dealings with the newspapers are also included.

bioghist.head: BIographical Note
bioghist.p: Thomas S. Mount (d. 1900) was a lawyer, politician, and scholar and a resident of Suffolk County, Long Island.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The source and date of acquisition for this collection are unknown. The collection was formally accessioned in 1973.
